awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Improving Fertility Patient-Provider Communication with a Personalized Natural Language Processing Platform
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact /commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to develop natural language processing software that will streamline communication between fertility clinic patients and their providers. Fertility clinics are specialized medical facilities that offer clinical diagnoses and treatments to assist with the conception of a child. Their patients undergo intense anxiety and large out-of-pocket expenses throughout their journey to conceive, and  up to two-thirds of patients at fertility clinics will discontinue their treatment regimen with emotional stress being cited as the primary reason. Patient satisfaction, which is more complex than just achieving desired outcomes, is correlated with how effectively care teams can navigate the large information disparity and bridge the communication gap. This project advances technologies to facilitate this communication. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will address major technical hurdles associated with natural language processing in healthcare, specifically fertility care. These challenges include that a conversational agent must understand the vocabulary particular to fertility-related questions, the natural language platform must overcome the difficulty in maintaining contextual-awareness throughout a continuous multi-person dialogue as well as understand ambiguous questions within a broader conversational context, and that the algorithm must reply with clinically accurate responses personalized to a specific patient. To meet these objectives, a fertility-specific corpus, or dictionary, will be developed from fertility stakeholders (patients, providers, and clinic staff) feedback, and a machine-learning algorithm will be developed that analyzes patient messages for intent and provides personalized responses drawing from the developed corpus in addition to external sources. Finally, a usability study will be performed to refine the platform’s user-interface, tone, and informational content. The anticipated result of the proposed research is a platform that improves both the quality and efficiency of patient-care team communication.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Patients undergoing evaluation and treatment for fertility conditions are often described as a 'highly motivated' patient population. They often enter their fertility treatment plan with limited knowledge of what is to come. Their initial patient education may come from internet searches, social media, or friends and family. The information they receive from these sources is often rife with inaccuracies and can exacerbate patient anxiety. This information deficit is part of a high-stress environment where actions are time-sensitive, and it is common for out-of-pocket expenses to reach tens of thousands of dollars. As such, fertility patients have many questions for their providers and expect quick answers from their providers.

Reproductive endocrinologists are bandwidth-limited with a typically full clinical schedule. Fertility clinics struggle to address the high volume of patient communications, and they primarily resort to an expensive human resources approach. Physicians often spend their rare downtime in the clinic (i.e., between patient appointments and lunch breaks) responding to patient messages. Additionally, fertility clinics often employ full-time 'inbox' nurses that dedicate their time only to answering inbound patient messages. Ultimately, responding to patient messages is a low-satisfaction task for staff. It does not drive any revenue -- providers are typically not compensated for responding to patient messages outside of scheduled patient visits -- but failure to manage patient communications promptly and adequately will result in a decrease in revenue. Amongst other reasons, fertility providers feel pressure to respond quickly to patient messages because: 1) they are acutely aware of the stresses of their patients, and understand faster responses reduce patient stress; 2) patient satisfaction is highly correlated with patients continuing their treatment, and patient dropout negatively impacts clinic finances. 

This Phase I SBIR sought to address the information gap between fertility patients and their providers, and simultaneously the bandwidth limit that these providers experience. This project aimed to develop a natural language processing engine that can understand inbound patient messages to fertility care providers and streamline a personalized, context-aware response. Ideally, this platform would sit in between patient portals and the clinic's Electronic Medical Record, where it would serve as a moderator of conversation between patients and providers. It could provide patients with informational content to answer their complex clinical questions related to personalized laboratory results or treatment regimens. Additional analytics on inbound messages can measure patient sentiment (a proxy for patient satisfaction), as well as identify staff efficiency improvements and opportunities for targeted patient education.

During the Phase I Award Period, a fertility-specific corpus with content vetted by medical experts was assembled. The corpus was used to build a natural language processing pipeline that reads an inbound patient message and processes it to determine the sender's intent (what task they are trying to accomplish or information they are trying to learn) and the message's sentiment (how positive or negative the tone of the message is). This pipeline can maintain conversational context and handle semantic similarity (two similar questions but formed using different words). The algorithm can personalize the responses with data from the patient's Electronic Medical Record, and then it returns the best potential reply to the inbound message to the provider for review. During expert evaluation, the algorithm was found to have 83% accuracy in returning satisfactory responses. This accuracy increased to greater than 95% when the top-3 responses were returned (one of the top-3 replies answered the patient's question satisfactorily).

After the natural language processing engine was built, multiple user-interface prototypes were developed for testing. These interfaces showcased the natural language processing engine and features that were identified as priorities for providers. After review, beta-testers completed the Computer System Usability Questionnaire, which was used to evaluate the platform's utility and usability. The overall platform passed usability thresholds, although areas for improvement were identified.

Future research and development will focus on expanding the corpus in the fertility domain and beyond. This expansion will include the addition of user 'scores' associated with each entry in the corpus, which can be used to bias outcomes in future models. Finally, algorithmic improvements will be made to leverage new data sources and state-of-the-art machine learning and natural language processing approaches to create more personalized responses. After further development and testing, this platform could have a significant positive impact on fertility patient and provider satisfaction.
